The Assignment Technical Focus â€¢ Use a shutter speed of at least 1/(2 Ã— focal length) when shooting handheld to avoid motion blur. â€¢ Set your camera to aperture priority mode and use an aperture of f/4 to maintain a good depth of field while allowing enough light. â€¢ When using a tripod, experiment with slower shutter speeds (e.g., 1/30s) to capture long exposures without camera shake. â€¢ Adjust the ISO to maintain exposure; for tripod shots, you might use ISO 100 to reduce noise. â€¢ Utilize manual focus when on a tripod for precise control over your subject, especially in low light. Creative Focus â€¢ Explore creative compositions by shooting handheld while walking to capture dynamic scenes. â€¢ Use a tripod for landscape photography to achieve long exposure effects, such as smooth water or blurred clouds. â€¢ Experiment with low angles and unique perspectives when shooting handheld to add interest to your images. â€¢ Incorporate motion blur creatively by lowering your shutter speed when handheld, such as 1/15s, while panning with a moving subject. â€¢ Try shooting handheld in low light conditions to capture the ambient atmosphere, adjusting settings to f/2.8, 1/60s, ISO 800. Assignment Tasks â€¢ Capture a portrait handheld at f/2.8, 1/100s, ISO 400 in aperture priority mode to test focus accuracy and background blur. â€¢ Take a landscape shot using a tripod at f/11, 1/30s, ISO 100 to emphasize depth of field and stability. â€¢ Shoot a moving subject handheld at f/4, 1/500s, ISO 800 in shutter priority mode to freeze the action while testing your grip. â€¢ Create a long exposure of a waterfall using a tripod at f/16, 2s, ISO 100 to achieve smooth water flow and motion blur. â€¢ Experiment with handheld shooting at f/5.6, 1/60s, ISO 1600 in low light to see how high ISO affects image quality. â€¢ Capture a night scene using a tripod at f/8, 15s, ISO 200 to create light trails and test the stability of your setup. ðŸ’¡ Stretch Tasks â€¢ Photograph a busy street scene with a handheld camera at f/4, 1/250s, ISO 400, then switch to a tripod for the same shot at f/8, 1/8s, ISO 100 to compare results. â€¢ Create a time-lapse video using a tripod, setting the camera at f/11, 30s, ISO 100, and adjust exposure settings throughout the shoot to capture changing light.
